user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_uint8_to_str_pad:
```c
size_t
MHD_uint8_to_str_pad (uint8_t val,
                      uint8_t min_digits,
                      char *buf,
                      size_t buf_size)
{
  size_t pos; /**< the position of the current printed digit */
  int digit;
  mhd_assert (3 >= min_digits);
  if (0 == buf_size)
    return 0;

  pos = 0;
  digit = val / 100;
  if (0 == digit)
  {
    if (3 <= min_digits)
      buf[pos++] = '0';
  }
  else
  {
    buf[pos++] = (char) ('0' + (char) digit);
    val %= 100;
    min_digits = 2;
  }

  if (buf_size <= pos)
    return 0;
  digit = val / 10;
  if (0 == digit)
  {
    if (2 <= min_digits)
      buf[pos++] = '0';
  }
  else
  {
    buf[pos++] = (char) ('0' + (char) digit);
    val %= 10;
  }

  if (buf_size <= pos)
    return 0;
  buf[pos++] = (char) ('0' + (char) val);
  return pos;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: Only modifications of function parameters are relevant to MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8. The three listed fragments are explicit assignments/updates to the value parameters (val and min_digits) and therefore must be investigated. Other code fragments do not modify parameters: reads of parameters (e.g. digit = val / 100; mhd_assert(3 >= min_digits); comparisons) are harmless for this rule; writes to buf (e.g. buf[pos++] = ...) modify the object pointed to by the pointer parameter which is permitted by the rule, and the pointer variable buf itself is never reassigned; local variables (pos, digit) are modified but they are not parameters. No other parameter assignments or pointer reassignments occur in the function, so no further fragments need investigation for Rule 17.8.
